channel.title: Comments on: Always include size when using varchar, nvarchar, char and nchar
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Jonas Gunnarsson
item.dc:creator: Jonas Gunnarsson
item.content:encoded:
List with schema name
<br />
SELECT [Schema] = OBJECT_SCHEMA_NAME([id]), Name<br />
FROM sys.sysobjects<br />
WHERE XType = 'P'<br />
    AND Object_Definition(id) LIKE '%varchar[^(]%'<br />
    AND ObjectProperty(id, N'IsMSShipped') = 0<br />
ORDER BY [Schema];<br />

item.title: By: Jane Dallaway
item.dc:creator: Jane Dallaway
item.content:encoded:
I get false positives from this one when the procedure has used a declaration such as @Name [nvarchar](128) = ”, as the first character after nvarchar is a ] rather than a (.

I’ve recoded to be
SELECT Name
FROM sys.sysobjects
WHERE XType = ‘P’
And Object_Definition(ID) Like ‘%varchar[^(]%’
AND Object_Definition(ID) NOT Like ‘%varchar](%’
And OBJECTPROPERTY(ID, N’IsMSShipped’) = 0
ORDER BY Name

to get around this. I’m sure there is a more elegant way ðŸ™‚

I also get false positives when CONVERT(VARCHAR, is being used within a procedure as well.

But, I’d rather have false positives, than no idea, so it is still a help…
